componenttext: Yes, Jeff, I'll remind you that as we get into the fourth quarter, it's going to be difficult. It's not impossible to break out sort of Broadview revenue versus the normal ADT revenue as we've combined all our marketing programs and the brands. So we'll just be the reporting on ADT revenue. And we'll highlight, obviously, the residential small-business piece of that.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Naren, just more specifically, as you think about these things together in kind of the notion of the best of both, probably in broad terms, the best on the ADT side is subscriber acquisition cost and it's attrition on the Broadview side. And I j
componenttext: And then, Naren, just more specifically, as you think about these things together in kind of the notion of the best of both, probably in broad terms, the best on the ADT side is subscriber acquisition cost and it's attrition on the Broadview side. And I just wonder, what your initial thoughts are now as you've six or eight weeks into this? Where those two can meet? And how you would target those going forward?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Jeff, we are still very early in the integration, so I'm hesitant to draw any conclusions at this time. But based on what we've seen -- and what we expected to see was they're very good from a customer service perspective. We found some inter
componenttext: Well, again, Jeff, we are still very early in the integration, so I'm hesitant to draw any conclusions at this time. But based on what we've seen -- and what we expected to see was they're very good from a customer service perspective. We found some interesting technologies that they used to serve customers better, and actually reduced the cost to serve on the service side, so not just on the attrition side. Clearly, they're very selective upfront on the account acquisition side. We still believe that we will get the subscriber acquisition down closer to where ADT was over time. And then attrition rates, again, for the combined business, we expect to continue to take those down in the same kind of progress we've seen over the past, I'd say, year, excluding the impact of the economy.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, I thought it was nice that we've had a lot of questions around will you have disconnects, because it's now going -- Broadview's going under ADT. You can tell by the disconnect rate -- the ADT disconnect rate improved sequentially, but so did Bro
componenttext: And Jeff, I thought it was nice that we've had a lot of questions around will you have disconnects, because it's now going -- Broadview's going under ADT. You can tell by the disconnect rate -- the ADT disconnect rate improved sequentially, but so did Broadview. And I think that's a real key indicator to kind of an answer to that question, because we've had a fair amount of communication already with the Broadview customer base. So they're well aware of what's taking place and all, and as you know, the attrition rate decline, I thought was a good sign.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Then, Naren, I was wondering if you could also just comment, then again, acknowledging it's probably early, but your initial thoughts on ARPU and what the subscriber acquisition cost looks like for interactive once you kind of include the higher sell, I g
componenttext: Then, Naren, I was wondering if you could also just comment, then again, acknowledging it's probably early, but your initial thoughts on ARPU and what the subscriber acquisition cost looks like for interactive once you kind of include the higher sell, I guess, that would happen at the time of the interactive?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, the one caution on this one is we have not really started the advertising campaign to support this. So whatever units we're getting are basically upsells at the kitchen table at this stage. From a pricing perspective, we'd targeted, depending on
componenttext: And Jeff, the one caution on this one is we have not really started the advertising campaign to support this. So whatever units we're getting are basically upsells at the kitchen table at this stage. From a pricing perspective, we'd targeted, depending on which of our three offerings they pursue, anywhere from a $10 to $15 increase in ARPU for those specific products, the kind of the $10 to $12 range, because we expect a mix to be more towards the lower end of the product offering there. Seems to be holding well, but again, we are very early in that rollout right now just in those five test markets. And the subscriber acquisition cost is higher, but that's up being offset by the higher install dollars that we get upfront. So from a net perspective, we're not seeing a significant change there.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some early thoughts on some of the high-level items for 2011? There's a lot of stuff moving around, tax rate, Broadview coming in, Naren gave us [indiscernible] number. We got to think about attempt's been -- just what are your overarching
componenttext: Can you give us some early thoughts on some of the high-level items for 2011? There's a lot of stuff moving around, tax rate, Broadview coming in, Naren gave us [indiscernible] number. We got to think about attempt's been -- just what are your overarching thoughts on how to frame 2011?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll maybe let Chris jump in maybe on corporate and tax in a moment. And I think Jeff just mentioned a couple of these here. But ADT, because of Broadview coming in, will add $0.10 to earnings next year, so that's a tailwind on an EPS basis. By the way, y
componenttext: I'll maybe let Chris jump in maybe on corporate and tax in a moment. And I think Jeff just mentioned a couple of these here. But ADT, because of Broadview coming in, will add $0.10 to earnings next year, so that's a tailwind on an EPS basis. By the way, you need to take about $0.20 out for Electrical & Metal because we're assuming the spend happens towards the beginning of the year. So that would come out of that number. And I would say, maybe just one other point is, the Flow because we're starting to see the orders improving -- by the way, and they did continue to improve during the month of July. But when you look at the backlog, how it's going in this conversion cycle we're talking about, I think you'll see a nicely stronger second half of next year for Flow, but probably still a little bit muted during the first half of the year until this increased order activity kicks in on a shipment basis. Chris, you might want to add a comment.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you look at our corporate expense, for example, I do expect that we'll be able to reduce that again, slightly from where we've been this year. On the tax front, it's still very early to determine what kind of a tax position we'll have. Obv
componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at our corporate expense, for example, I do expect that we'll be able to reduce that again, slightly from where we've been this year. On the tax front, it's still very early to determine what kind of a tax position we'll have. Obviously, we've done a terrific job since the separation in reducing that tax rate, and as we've indicated, Broadview will be a positive. We've got taxing authorities around the world looking at their tax policies right now. So I think between that and obviously, what ends up being our geographic mix of revenues and profits could impact that. But again, we've done a good job in holding that. I don't think anything dramatic there. And then obviously, we'll have the impacts of the share repurchase as we continue to reduce our share count and offset some of that impact of the Broadview acquisition. And then obviously, the refinancing that we have just completed will reduce our interest expense as well.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Inch with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Inch with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Naren or Ed or Chris, did you take up the Broadview accretion expectation? I know that you had said $0.07 in the first fiscal year. How does that dovetail with kind of a couple of quarters or quarter and a half of ownership in fiscal '10 versus fiscal '11
componenttext: Naren or Ed or Chris, did you take up the Broadview accretion expectation? I know that you had said $0.07 in the first fiscal year. How does that dovetail with kind of a couple of quarters or quarter and a half of ownership in fiscal '10 versus fiscal '11? And are we still on track for the -- I mean if you parse this all together, what does that imply for fiscal '12, that second year of ownership, et cetera?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, I think it's consistent with what we talked about when we announced the deal. The only difference  is we've talked about first 12 months and second 12 months, and now we're just kind of calendarizing it around our fiscal year. So no change at all.
componenttext: John, I think it's consistent with what we talked about when we announced the deal. The only difference  is we've talked about first 12 months and second 12 months, and now we're just kind of calendarizing it around our fiscal year. So no change at all.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So the $0.10, Naren, if you go back to the way you would originally lay this out, first 12 months, second 12 months, how does that roll through to fiscal '12? Is that like the $0.15 accretion number is a little bit higher?
componenttext: So the $0.10, Naren, if you go back to the way you would originally lay this out, first 12 months, second 12 months, how does that roll through to fiscal '12? Is that like the $0.15 accretion number is a little bit higher?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say it's in that range. When we talked originally, we said $0.07 for the first 12 months and $0.14 for the second 12 months. So I think you're in the range.
componenttext: Yes, I would say it's in that range. When we talked originally, we said $0.07 for the first 12 months and $0.14 for the second 12 months. So I think you're in the range.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then what were exactly were purchase accounting charges, not restructuring charges but purchase accounting charges, for Broadview in the quarter? And then I'm just trying to understand, is your guidance, going forward, going to be including Broadview
componenttext: And then what were exactly were purchase accounting charges, not restructuring charges but purchase accounting charges, for Broadview in the quarter? And then I'm just trying to understand, is your guidance, going forward, going to be including Broadview restructuring charges as part of the integration or are you excluding those? That's not really clear.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take that, John. First, in 2010, in the guidance that we have provided, the restructuring and acquisition costs related to the transaction, we have excluded from the guidance. The impact of the purchase accounting, which includes adjustments to the
componenttext: Let me take that, John. First, in 2010, in the guidance that we have provided, the restructuring and acquisition costs related to the transaction, we have excluded from the guidance. The impact of the purchase accounting, which includes adjustments to the deferred revenue base, as well as the subscriber asset base which needs to be amortized, those are operating costs that we have included in our guidance for the year. So there are a lot of adjustments that happened and some pretty complicated purchase accounting adjustments, which generated this $8 million loss for the quarter. Again, that's for a six-week-kind-of-time period. But the normal operating margin that we saw Broadview as a stand alone were essentially the margins that we achieved in the quarter. So no real change there, it's just the noise from the purchase accounting. So I hope that clarifies it.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Chris, from the $0.72 operations versus the $0.50 GAAP, how much of that was Broadview-associated charges?
componenttext: And Chris, from the $0.72 operations versus the $0.50 GAAP, how much of that was Broadview-associated charges?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: There were $37 million of what I'll call one-time restructuring charges and acquisition costs. That was going from the $0.72 down to the $0.50, but then included in the $0.72 is an $8 million loss from Broadview which is the result of having to write off
componenttext: There were $37 million of what I'll call one-time restructuring charges and acquisition costs. That was going from the $0.72 down to the $0.50, but then included in the $0.72 is an $8 million loss from Broadview which is the result of having to write off things like the deferred revenue balance and writing off some of the subscriber base and additional amortization.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just curious on the TEMP spin, perhaps this is a question for Ed. Have your thoughts towards prospectively selling this business changed? I'm just trying to think out loud, as clearly, I'm assuming people have perhaps expressed an interest in the business
componenttext: Just curious on the TEMP spin, perhaps this is a question for Ed. Have your thoughts towards prospectively selling this business changed? I'm just trying to think out loud, as clearly, I'm assuming people have perhaps expressed an interest in the business and to announce the spin. What are your thoughts towards a spin versus a sale at this point?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, we're still down the road of clearly going towards the spin. We've heard some rumblings out there, that there might be some interest in the business but nothing definitive. My gut is we'll know that answer over the next 60 to 75 days. And if we did
componenttext: John, we're still down the road of clearly going towards the spin. We've heard some rumblings out there, that there might be some interest in the business but nothing definitive. My gut is we'll know that answer over the next 60 to 75 days. And if we did get an offer, clearly, we will assess that and see what the best avenue is for our shareholders. But I'm really -- my thinking at this point, clearly, is we're headed down the spin route.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, I would also add, I mean, we've obviously talked about this business since the separation and what the dramatic impact that the economy has had on that business and their competitors, the strategic, what you would think of strategic buyers, are in v
componenttext: John, I would also add, I mean, we've obviously talked about this business since the separation and what the dramatic impact that the economy has had on that business and their competitors, the strategic, what you would think of strategic buyers, are in very poor financial position, actually I don't know if this is a much better shape than any others. So I mean that also impacts that decision.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, there's quite of a gap between Broadview's ARPU and your residential legacy ADT, residential ARPU. Can you just maybe talk about some of the strategies that you have to maybe get up to improve the Broadview ARPU closer towards your legacy?
componenttext: Obviously, there's quite of a gap between Broadview's ARPU and your residential legacy ADT, residential ARPU. Can you just maybe talk about some of the strategies that you have to maybe get up to improve the Broadview ARPU closer towards your legacy?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, Nigel, when you look at just our residential business against Broadview business, the gap is not as significant. When you look at our total ARPU, it gets distorted a little bit because of the commercial side of our business. That said, th
componenttext: Just to clarify, Nigel, when you look at just our residential business against Broadview business, the gap is not as significant. When you look at our total ARPU, it gets distorted a little bit because of the commercial side of our business. That said, there is a small gap between the two, and it's really driven more by the content of what they were selling. They had a very simplified package that they were offering. And as we look to add more sensors, more devices there, there's an opportunity to take up that ARPU over time. And again, as we bring the sales force together and standardize the product offering and stuff for that combined sales force, there should be a little bit of a pick up there.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you maybe just quantify what the impact of Broadview with the purchase accounting charges, what the impact was on ADT margins during the quarter? And maybe then secondly on top of that, your expectation for the contribution in 4Q within your
componenttext: And then can you maybe just quantify what the impact of Broadview with the purchase accounting charges, what the impact was on ADT margins during the quarter? And maybe then secondly on top of that, your expectation for the contribution in 4Q within your guidance?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Nigel, if you take a look at ADT and you kind of adjust, because we also had, remember, the pension benefit in the quarter of about $12 million and you also adjust for the impact of Broadview, if we do an apples to apples ADT, how we have previously repor
componenttext: Nigel, if you take a look at ADT and you kind of adjust, because we also had, remember, the pension benefit in the quarter of about $12 million and you also adjust for the impact of Broadview, if we do an apples to apples ADT, how we have previously reported, the margin was about 15.3%.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But that includes Broadview?
componenttext: But that includes Broadview?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, when you exclude Broadview. If you exclude Broadview, OI was around $271 million and the OI margin was about 15.3%.
componenttext: No, when you exclude Broadview. If you exclude Broadview, OI was around $271 million and the OI margin was about 15.3%.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And the contribution in 4Q from Broadview within the EBIT number?
componenttext: And the contribution in 4Q from Broadview within the EBIT number?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, overall, we gave a total revenue number and a total OI number. And as Naren and Chris had mentioned before, as we move forward, it becomes more and more difficult to completely separate Broadview from the total, as again, everything is going to be c
componenttext: Well, overall, we gave a total revenue number and a total OI number. And as Naren and Chris had mentioned before, as we move forward, it becomes more and more difficult to completely separate Broadview from the total, as again, everything is going to be completely integrated as we move into the fourth quarter.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But it'll be positive. What happens though, again, I'll try to explain this. The revenue impact of -- we lose about $10 million a quarter because of the deferred revenue which is written off, and we have $13 million to $14 million of additional amortizati
componenttext: But it'll be positive. What happens though, again, I'll try to explain this. The revenue impact of -- we lose about $10 million a quarter because of the deferred revenue which is written off, and we have $13 million to $14 million of additional amortization each quarter. But again, once we get into this quarter, all the revenue was combined, so that's why we're just going to give the overall perspective of ADT.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Nigel, one other thing that I would add, is as we've said before is if the transaction in total was a little bit dilutive to our earnings this quarter and it's a little bit accretive next quarter. So for the full year, we're neutral.
componenttext: And Nigel, one other thing that I would add, is as we've said before is if the transaction in total was a little bit dilutive to our earnings this quarter and it's a little bit accretive next quarter. So for the full year, we're neutral.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as you move towards a full rollout of Pulse in the next 12 months, I mean, is that going to be a material drag to ADT margins?
componenttext: And then as you move towards a full rollout of Pulse in the next 12 months, I mean, is that going to be a material drag to ADT margins?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't expect it to be a drag.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't expect it to be a drag.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally on the EMEA margins within  ADT, I think you've called out a three-point impact from the pension on these margins?
componenttext: And then just finally on the EMEA margins within  ADT, I think you've called out a three-point impact from the pension on these margins?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So it was 12.1%, including that pension benefit. If you back that out, it was a 9.1% for the quarter.
componenttext: So it was 12.1%, including that pension benefit. If you back that out, it was a 9.1% for the quarter.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think you mentioned there's a two-point benefit from the France disposal?
componenttext: And I think you mentioned there's a two-point benefit from the France disposal?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: A little less than that.
componenttext: A little less than that.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Year-over-year, France contributed about 140 basis points to the margin improvement.
componenttext: Yes. Year-over-year, France contributed about 140 basis points to the margin improvement.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So on a comparable basis, we're sort of in the high sevens on EMEA margins?
componenttext: So on a comparable basis, we're sort of in the high sevens on EMEA margins?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, fairly same to last year with France, then yes.
componenttext: Yes, fairly same to last year with France, then yes.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Winoker with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Winoker with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just first question on the Waterworks European disposal divestiture, you mentioned that it's been in the high-single digits today. What were the margins at peak? I'm just trying to work through the multiples if you go back in time.
componenttext: Just first question on the Waterworks European disposal divestiture, you mentioned that it's been in the high-single digits today. What were the margins at peak? I'm just trying to work through the multiples if you go back in time.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: About high-single digits. As I pointed out and that's why I went through it, it's more couplings, fittings, products like that. It's not our highly engineered type products, Steve. So [indiscernible] strategically, that was one of the reasons. It's a nice
componenttext: About high-single digits. As I pointed out and that's why I went through it, it's more couplings, fittings, products like that. It's not our highly engineered type products, Steve. So [indiscernible] strategically, that was one of the reasons. It's a nice business for someone else to own. But for us strategically, it's more on the lower end of what we were doing and didn't play to our global platform strategy. So that's about what it was. It's running right now about as well as it was.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's about 8x EBITDA.
componenttext: It's about 8x EBITDA.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're saying that margins have been pretty consistent despite the volume changes over time?
componenttext: So you're saying that margins have been pretty consistent despite the volume changes over time?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just broadly speaking then, how do you think about your overall Tyco European business strategy developing? What does Tyco look like in Europe as you work your way through all of these divestitures now?
componenttext: And then just broadly speaking then, how do you think about your overall Tyco European business strategy developing? What does Tyco look like in Europe as you work your way through all of these divestitures now?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as Chris mentioned, our restructuring, Steve, is going to go down because we now look like we're going to be able to sell some, what I'll call, smaller non-strategic operations. And just ballpark you, we're talking now, we're down to kind of maybe $
componenttext: Well, as Chris mentioned, our restructuring, Steve, is going to go down because we now look like we're going to be able to sell some, what I'll call, smaller non-strategic operations. And just ballpark you, we're talking now, we're down to kind of maybe $100 million to $120 million of revenue with a very marginal bottom line performance. So that's kind of the ballpark of what we're talking. And it's both a little bit on the Fire side and a little bit on the Security Side, then we'll be pretty much done with, I'd say, that program. Steve, what I feel good about is we're getting much better discipline around our lead process, what we're going after, what we're not going after, the verticals we want, the verticals we don't want. So we are, as Chris mentioned, we're purposely more on the Fire than ADT side but both sides of the business, we're purposely reducing our organic revenue growth a little bit on purpose, because we're not going after some verticals. And we are clearly though seeing the benefit of that in the bottom line margin performance of the business. So as Naren said, if I look at it, with the divestitures we've done, with the restructuring and the selectivity of bidding, we've got the margins this quarter at 9.1% on a true run-rate basis on the ADT side, and you can see very nice margin improvement occurring on the international Fire side, which is really for the same reasons. So I think we're -- in the next, I'd say, two quarters or so, I would say we're clicking about where we want to be with the portfolio, and it won't change from there.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Chris, maybe you could talk about a little more detail on that $52 million legal reserve? You mentioned the liabilities and just maybe give us a little more color there?
componenttext: And Chris, maybe you could talk about a little more detail on that $52 million legal reserve? You mentioned the liabilities and just maybe give us a little more color there?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. As we do every year, we perform our annual analysis of expenses-related liabilities and the related insurance assets that we have, which we did this quarter. And we do that, we base on our claims experience that goes back over the last five y
componenttext: Sure, Steve. As we do every year, we perform our annual analysis of expenses-related liabilities and the related insurance assets that we have, which we did this quarter. And we do that, we base on our claims experience that goes back over the last five years, and then we look out over the next seven. And then so as we completed that analysis this quarter, we decided that we should increase that reserve by the $52 million. And again, that charge is included in corporate expense. So again, this is more of a one-time catch up.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean have you seen a material change on the asbestos side that is driving some of that curtailment [ph]?
componenttext: I mean have you seen a material change on the asbestos side that is driving some of that curtailment [ph]?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, a material change right now going forward. Obviously, there are lot of variables that go in that in terms of claims, which go up in certain periods, go down at other periods. So we may face a $10 million kind of a headwind going in on our annual expen
componenttext: No, a material change right now going forward. Obviously, there are lot of variables that go in that in terms of claims, which go up in certain periods, go down at other periods. So we may face a $10 million kind of a headwind going in on our annual expense, not on the $52 million. So that sort of what we see right now.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the non-GAAP tax rate, the 6% number, is that all -- is that mostly results on the acquisition side or is there something else going on there?
componenttext: And then on the non-GAAP tax rate, the 6% number, is that all -- is that mostly results on the acquisition side or is there something else going on there?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No. There are some other tax planning activities that we had planned on completing this year, but again, it's difficult to pin the exact timing. So what's included in our guidance, it actually came out a little bit better than our guidance. But it was tha
componenttext: No. There are some other tax planning activities that we had planned on completing this year, but again, it's difficult to pin the exact timing. So what's included in our guidance, it actually came out a little bit better than our guidance. But it was that -- the full impact of that plus the Broadview acquisition that drove it down. So again, I think as you look at our results quarter-to-quarter, the way they really look at each quarter is just use the annual tax rate of 15% to 16%.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question on capital allocation, you've been talking about, sort of an acquisition on the order of a few hundred million or dollars around that previously. Are you still thinking about that? You want to give us a sense for that given your com
componenttext: And then last question on capital allocation, you've been talking about, sort of an acquisition on the order of a few hundred million or dollars around that previously. Are you still thinking about that? You want to give us a sense for that given your comments on share repurchases, et cetera.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steve, we haven't changed our thinking. We're looking at some acquisitions stuff that could be up to $500 million and one we're looking at who knows if we'll get over the finish line, it'll be a couple of hundred million. So it's that type of range.
componenttext: Yes. Steve, we haven't changed our thinking. We're looking at some acquisitions stuff that could be up to $500 million and one we're looking at who knows if we'll get over the finish line, it'll be a couple of hundred million. So it's that type of range. I'd say right down in the middle of the plate in either Fire, Flow or Security. But even with that, when we model out our capital plan going forward, we're in a nice position to still have excess cash. We're funding all our internal capital, we're funding all our growth initiatives. So we've been very comfortable. You can see from what we previously guided through last quarter, we did significantly more share repurchase during the quarter. And if we do the $325 million more here in the fourth quarter, we will have done $900 million in about four and a half months.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And at acquisitions of the size, you're talking about -- you would not be talking about additional share issuance, right, in those deals?
componenttext: And at acquisitions of the size, you're talking about -- you would not be talking about additional share issuance, right, in those deals?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Most likely not.
componenttext: Most likely not.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just starting on Flow, the orders are up, I guess, 4% but you had talked about being up double digit in April and May. Is there a tougher compare in June? Or what happened in June? Because then you said July has actually remained pretty good?
componenttext: Just starting on Flow, the orders are up, I guess, 4% but you had talked about being up double digit in April and May. Is there a tougher compare in June? Or what happened in June? Because then you said July has actually remained pretty good?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steve, look, it's a very lumpy business. We actually thought a couple of big orders would hit June, it did not. But we ended up pretty flat in June. So you're correct, we were up higher in April and May, kind of down flat in June and therefore, we en
componenttext: Yes. Steve, look, it's a very lumpy business. We actually thought a couple of big orders would hit June, it did not. But we ended up pretty flat in June. So you're correct, we were up higher in April and May, kind of down flat in June and therefore, we ended up at 4.3% for the quarter. I did feel pretty good that we had about the same results here in July, which we just preliminarily rolled up yesterday. So that feels good. But I guess what I've been watching because it is a lumpy and one or two big orders can really sway it, I'm looking at that the lead Flow that our sales team is working on and it feels very robust right now. And there's a couple of big, what I call elephant deals that I don't know when they're going to book, but I have a high confidence that we're going to get a couple of these. So again, the flow of it feels good coming in with the sales team. And not to talk about competition per se, but I have noticed a few other flow control companies also saying that their sales activity this quarter just feels pretty robust and they're feeling good. So I'm not declaring victory that we've turned the quarter, but it's two quarters in a row now of organic growth. And if you go back, fiscal '09, this business was -- the orders were down over 20% as well as the competitors report. In the first quarter, we improved that to down 13%. And now the second and third quarter and July, now positive with good lead generation. So I think it bodes well, kind of for the second half of next fiscal year.

componenttext: Well, Steve, again, our Fire business, still similar actually to our Flow Business, is a much later-cycle business. And what we saw at the end of last year was the work off of the backlog during that period, then the order intake started to decline. So it was really that impact that we saw similar to what we saw in Flow.

componenttext: Again, I can't run through all of the numbers with you right now. But, again, if you look at the annualized revenue that Broadview had less some of the deferred revenue charges, add back to $65 million, add back the shares and take out then the tax impact, which is about 2% on an overall tax rate, you do all that math and it comes out to about a $0.10 on the first-year basis.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Bob, for us, the synergies, I don't think they're going to be hard to track though. We've got a very detailed schedule because we didn't count on revenues synergies per se in the deal, as you know. We didn't counter ARPU going up that some of these questions create [ph]. It's all cost actions and tax, the two full percentage points on the type of tax line is $50 million and the other part of it is all cost actions that we're tracking against: headcount moves, consolidation of facilities, that we can actually count the hard dollars on the cost side against.

componenttext: No, we're not. Again, the conversion time in Flow is kind of six to nine months. Component suppliers are tight, and we're really managing that closely.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Welcome to the Tyco Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Antonella Franzen, Director of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining our conference call to discuss Tycos third quarter results for fiscal year 2010 and the press release issued earlier this morning. With me today are Tycos Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ed Breen
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining our conference call to discuss Tycos third quarter results for fiscal year 2010 and the press release issued earlier this morning. With me today are Tycos Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Ed Breen; our Chief Financial Officer, Chris Coughlin; as well as Naren Gursahaney, President of ADT Worldwide.
Let me remind you that during the course of the call, we will be providing certain forward-looking information. We ask you to look at today's press release and read through the forward-looking cautionary informational statements that we've included there. In addition, we will use certain non-GAAP measures in our discussions, and we ask you to read through the sections of our press release that address the use of these items. The press releases issued this morning and all related tables, as well as the conference call slides, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at tyco.com.
Now let me quickly recap this quarter's results. Revenue in the quarter of $4.3 billion was up 3% year-over-year with flat organic revenue. Earnings per share from continuing operations attributable to Tyco common shareholders was $0.50 per share and included $0.22 per share related to special items.
Before special items, earnings per share was $0.72 compared to our guidance of $0.60 to $0.62 per share.  The $0.72 per share compares to the midpoint of our guidance of $0.61. The $0.11 difference consisted primarily of $0.07 of better operating results, $0.10 attributable to a lower tax rate, offset by a net fixed [ph] charge for a legal reserve and a benefit from certain pension plan changes.
Now let me turn the call over to Ed Breen for some opening comments. Ed will be followed by Naren, who will discuss our ADT business, and then Chris will review the results from our other businesses before we wrap up and take your questions.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Antonella, and good morning, everyone. Overall, this was a good quarter for Tyco. From an operational perspective, we saw sequential improvement in revenue and operating margin across all business segments. Additionally, we completed the acquisiti
componenttext:
Thanks, Antonella, and good morning, everyone. Overall, this was a good quarter for Tyco. From an operational perspective, we saw sequential improvement in revenue and operating margin across all business segments. Additionally, we completed the acquisition of Broadview Security and are well underway with the integration process and are very excited about the opportunities of joining the best of both ADT and Broadview. From a capital perspective, we invested more to strengthen our businesses and returned excess cash to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
Let me start off with a few overall comments. First, the majority of our segments, including the service side of our Fire business, grew revenue organically year-over-year. The systems installation and service side of our ADT business turned positive after six consecutive quarters of organic revenue decline.
Operating margins improved both year-over-year and sequentially, driven by our cost management efforts and the continued growth of our recurring revenue and service activities. Additionally, increased volume in our product and manufacturing businesses also contributed to the operating margin improvement.
From an orders perspective, it's important to keep in mind that our Service and Recurring revenue businesses have been growing and represent 40% of our total revenue. Orders for the remaining 60% of our portfolio, which is our Product and Systems Installation revenue, grew 5% year-over-year on a global basis, with order growth in Flow Control, Fire and Safety Products.
Second, our free cash flow generation continues to be strong and provides us with the financial flexibility to fund our organic growth investment activities, make selective acquisitions and return excess cash to our shareholders.
As we indicated last quarter, we resumed our share repurchase program and to date, have repurchased 15.8 million shares for $575 million. We expect to continue repurchasing shares during the fourth quarter, and we'll likely utilize the remaining 325 million authorization under the program by our fiscal year end.
Now let me make a few quick comments or two about each of our businesses, and then Naren and Chris will provide you with more details in a few minutes.
Starting with ADT, our recurring revenue continued to perform well with 4% organic revenue growth. Excluding Broadview, our account base and ARPU both increased and the disconnect rate continued to improve.
Additionally, the Systems Installation business has stabilized. Growth in the Asia-Pacific and Latin America regions and improving conditions in North America offset the continued softness in Europe.
We also saw a continued improvement in our operating margin both sequentially and year-over-year. Growth in our higher-margin recurring revenue business, coupled with the benefits of restructuring activities and cost actions, as well as improved productivity and mix in our Systems Installation business, contributed nicely to the operating margin improvement.
Turning to Flow Control. Performance in the quarter was as expected, sequential improvement in revenue and operating income and continued growth in order activity. The announced divestiture of our Waterworks business in Europe is another step in focusing our portfolio on industries and products that we can leverage on a global basis.
This business, which sells to markets in Europe, makes products such as hydrants, fittings, couplings and valves primarily for the transmission and distribution of water for residential use. Our intention is to grow our Flow Control business with global products and services that utilize advanced technology and critical applications.
Next, our Fire business had operating margin improvement, both sequentially and year-over-year despite the continued pressure on the top line. More importantly, the quarter marked a turning point to positive order activity, and backlog continued to grow.
Next, the continued investments we have made in our Safety Products business to fund our growth plans and maintain our R&D, sales and marketing spend throughout the economic downturn are starting to pay off. We are well positioned for a recovery and have seen the benefit of increased volume in our operating margin, which improved 350 basis points year-over-year.
And finally, Electrical and Metal products performed a bit better than expected in the quarter due to improved pricing for both steel and copper products. The previously announced tax re-spin of this business to our shareholders continues to move forward, and we are tracking to complete the separation within the first half of our fiscal year 2011.
Overall, we saw improving conditions across all our businesses in the quarter. The top line stabilized, operating margins increased and order activity improved. Additionally, we made good progress focusing our portfolio around our three-core platforms of Security, Fire and Flow Control.
Now let me turn the call over to Naren to review our performance in ADT and provide you with an update on the Broadview integration process.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed, and good morning, everyone. ADT continued to show good progress against all of our key financial and operating metrics. Revenue in the quarter was $1.8 billion, with organic revenue growth for the first time in several quarters growing at 3%.
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed, and good morning, everyone. ADT continued to show good progress against all of our key financial and operating metrics. Revenue in the quarter was $1.8 billion, with organic revenue growth for the first time in several quarters growing at 3%. Recurring revenue continued to grow nicely at 4%, driven by our North America residential and small-business operations. We also continued to see nice recurring revenue growth in Asia-Pacific and Latin America.
Systems Installation service revenue grew slightly on an organic basis, up almost 0.5%. While we still saw declines in North America and EMEA, the declines were very modest compared to what we've seen in the past. These declines were offset by 17% organic revenue growth in the Rest of the World.
Before special items, operating income was $275 million and the operating margin was 15.1%. Excluding the impact of Broadview and a $12 million benefit in the quarter related to certain pension plan changes, the operating income before special items was $271 million and the operating margin was 15.3%, a 170 basis point improvement year-over-year. While a portion of this improvement is the result of our improved business mix with more of the higher-margin recurring revenue, we are also reaping the benefits of our restructuring and other cost reduction initiatives, including our operational excellence initiatives.
We also saw continued progress in improving customer retention, with the 30-basis-point improvement in our attrition rate to 12.8%. Our account base now stands at over 8.8 million recurring customers, including the addition of the Broadview account base of 1.4 million customers. Excluding Broadview, we grew our account base by 3% and our average revenue per user grew 1% to $45.72, excluding the impact of foreign currency, which is consistent with what we've seen over the past several quarters. As Broadview's customer base was nearly 100% residential compared to ADT's mix of residential and commercial customers, the new blended overall ARPU decreased by 4% to $43.42 per account.
In terms of regional performance, we continue to see solid performance in our North America residential business where units in ARPU growth were consistent with what we've seen over the past several quarters.  Although the commercial side of our North America business remains soft, we are seeing increased activities in certain vertical markets like retail. Despite the 3% decline in organic revenue, our operating margin improved 110 basis points year-over-year as the benefits of our restructuring and cost containment actions more than offset the revenue headwind.
In EMEA, we continue to see strong margin improvement in both the U.K. and Continental Europe. The operating margin before special items of 12.1% increased 820 basis points year-over-year and 560 basis points on a quarter-sequential basis. These results included a $12 million benefit related to certain pension plan changes, which contributed 300 basis points to the margin improvement. With these trends, we continue to feel good about achieving our 10% target by the end of 2011.
In the Rest of the World, which includes several of our key emerging markets, we are seeing solid top and bottom line growth. Growth was 10% for recurring revenue, while Systems Installation and Service revenue growth was in the mid to high teens. We continue to invest in emerging markets and remain excited by the opportunities we see there.
Much of our focus during the third quarter was on the closing of the Broadview acquisition and the initial stages of integration of this business into our North America residential and small-business platform. As you are aware, we closed the deal in the middle of May, so our results include about six weeks of Broadview this quarter. Broadview's impact on the quarter was an operating loss of $8 million, primarily driven by the purchase accounting impact of the transaction that we mentioned when we announced the deal.
As we move forward, it'll become more difficult to call our Broadview results separately as we are fully integrating the business into our ADT residential and small-business platform. We've adapted the best of both approach to integration and are committed to leveraging the best people, processes and technology from both organizations as we build our new ADT North America residential business.
John Koch, who's been leading our ADT North America business for the past four years, will lead this combined business. John has assembled a leadership team that includes several key leaders from both ADT and Broadview. We are very pleased with the progress we've made so far in our integration efforts, and we remain confident that we'll deliver on the synergy and accretion expectations that we stated when we announced the deal.
On a fiscal-year basis, we expect the impact to be neutral in fiscal 2010 and accretive by about $0.10 in fiscal 2011. The accretion estimate includes the impact of non-cash purchase accounting charges. Looking at this on a cash basis, the fiscal 2011 accretion is actually $0.18 per share.
Much of our current efforts are focused on the marketing side as we prepare to migrate away from the Broadview brand and consolidate all of our lead generation to the ADT brand. We expect to finalize this transition during the fourth quarter.
We have also begun to train our sales teams on the standard set of product offerings and are moving forward to integrate our field teams into a common management structure. In addition, we've focused considerable time and effort on communications with both our customers and our employees. While we're still early in the process, the response from customers appears to be favorable, with both businesses showing modest improvements in retention on a quarter-sequential basis.
Finally, I thought I'd comment on the rollout of our new interactive services platform, ADT Pulse. As we indicated in the past, we've launched our operational pilots during the third quarter and are currently operating these solutions in five test markets across the country. These are operational pilots focused on developing our capabilities to sell, install and service these new solutions which combine life safety with life style. The initial customer response has been positive with no marketing and advertising support. We are also seeing a nice pick up in our installation fees and ARPU. 
We are currently ramping up our training efforts and expect to expand from our current pilot approach to a full market-by-market national rollout later this calendar year. I look forward to updating you on our progress with ADT Pulse during future calls.
Before I turn it over to Chris, let me provide you with our guidance for the fourth quarter. We expect revenue to approximate $1.9 billion, with an operating margin before special items of approximately 16%.  
Now let me turn the call over to Chris.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Naren, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with Flow Control. As Ed mentioned, we announced a definitive agreement to sell our Waterworks business in Europe for approximately $245 million. The transaction is expected to close in our fourth quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Naren, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with Flow Control. As Ed mentioned, we announced a definitive agreement to sell our Waterworks business in Europe for approximately $245 million. The transaction is expected to close in our fourth quarter and is now reported in Discontinued Operations.
On an annual basis, this business generates about $350 million of revenue with an operating margin in the high-single digits. Approximately $0.01 per share in the quarter and an estimated $0.05 per share for the year has moved to Discontinued Operations.
During the quarter, Flow Control had revenue of $849 million, which again, excludes the revenue from our European Waterworks businesses. Organic revenue declined 7% as the 11% growth in Water and the 16% growth in Thermal Control were more than offset by a 17% decline in the Valves business. As expected, the organic revenue decline has moderated. The 7% decline this quarter compares to a 14% decline in the first quarter and a 13% decline in the second quarter.
Before special items, operating income was $119 million and the operating margin was 14%. Despite the volume deleveraging, the operating margin performance in the quarter was similar to last year due to increased activity in our Pacific Water business related to the Australian desalinization (sic)[desalination] project.  Additionally, the operating margin continued to benefit from our cost management and restructuring activities.
For the second consecutive quarter, we have seen year-over-year growth in orders which is encouraging. Excluding currency, orders grew 4% year-over-year. It's important to keep in mind that there is a six to nine month order-to-revenue conversion cycle in Flow. So the recent order activity we are seeing will most likely impact our fiscal year 2011. Backlog of $1.5 billion declined 3% on a quarter-sequential basis, again, excluding the impact of foreign currency, primarily driven by the shipments of products for the Australian desalinization (sic)[desalination] project.
As we look to the fourth quarter, we expect continued improvement in organic revenue with a year-over-year organic revenue decline in the mid-single digits. While our revenue will grow sequentially, product mix in the quarter is expected to result in an operating margin before special items of approximately 13%.
Turning now to our Fire business. Revenue in the quarter was $822 million and the organic revenue declined 6%. Service revenue grew 2% organically, offset by a continued weakness in System Installation which declined 13% organically. Our strategy to be more selective in our project work has contributed to the organic revenue decline.  However, the benefit of this discipline can be seen in our improved earnings and operating margin performance.
Before special items, operating income was $85 million and the operating margin was 10.3%. Operating results were positively impacted by a $7 million benefit related to certain pension plan changes, which improved the operating margin by 80 basis points. The remaining improvement in operating margin of 110 basis points resulted from the benefits of our restructuring actions, cost containment activities and the selectivity in project work which more than offset the revenue decline. We expect operating income before special items in the fourth quarter to approximate the third quarter level, excluding that pension benefit.
Year-over-year, orders turned positive, growing 4%, again, excluding the impact of foreign currency. Backlog of $1.2 billion increased 5% on a quarter-sequential basis, excluding the impact of foreign currency.
Moving now to Safety Products. Revenue grew 5% in the quarter to $389 million with an organic revenue growth of 6.5%. The revenue growth was driven by strong performance in Electronics Security, which grew 15% organically and Life Safety, which grew 14% organically. Organic revenue was flat in Fire Suppression after five quarters of double-digit organic decline.
Before special items, operating income was $65 million and operating margin improved 350 basis points to 16.7%. Higher revenue and better productivity, coupled with savings from our restructuring actions and cost-containment activities, more than offset our continued investments in sales, marketing and R&D. On a year-over-year you basis, we expect organic revenue growth to be similar to the third quarter with an operating margin of approximately 16%.
Lastly, Electrical and Metal products have revenue of $390 million, with an organic revenue growth of 15%. Year-over-year revenue growth was primarily due to higher selling prices for both steel and copper products. Although demand has stabilized, volume remains at historically low levels 
Despite the continued low volume, the operating income before special items of $41 million was better than expected and represents a significant improvement over the prior year's operating loss of $6 million. The $47 million increase in operating income is primarily due to better steel spreads. 
Looking to the fourth quarter, we have seen steel prices weaken in recent weeks after increasing sharply in the first half of the calendar year. Based on current market dynamics, we expect revenue of $375 million and operating income of approximately $30 million.
So before I turn the call back over to Ed, let me touch on a few other important items. As you have just heard, certain of our defined benefit plans were converted to defined contribution plans resulting in a $22 million benefit in the quarter, which has been reported in our business segment results. Next, we performed a number of actuarial evaluations during the second half of the year to determine if there are any liability reserves which need adjustment. As a result, we increased the legal reserve by $52 million which is reported in corporate expense. Including this charge, corporate expense before special items in the quarter was $142 million. Looking to the fourth quarter, we expect corporate expense to be approximately $115 million, bringing our full year corporate expense to about $450 million.
Turning to interest expense. We issued $500 million of bonds at a very attractive interest rate. Additionally, we redeemed approximately $875 million of outstanding bonds, resulting in an $87 million charge in the quarter which again is included in special items.
Next, our tax rate for the quarter was approximately 6%, well below the rate we guided to last quarter. We had expected our annual tax rate to be in the 17% to 18% range, and now believe our tax rate for the full year will be in the range of 15% to 16%. This improvement reflects the impact of our tax planning activities as well as the Broadview acquisition.
As we have discussed in the past, the timing and the impact of tax items can move the rate significantly quarter to quarter. We expect the fourth quarter's tax rate to approximate 23%. We intend to continue repurchasing shares in the fourth quarter and expect our average share count to be about $500 million in the fourth quarter, as it will include the full impact of the shares issued for the Broadview acquisition.
I also want to touch for a minute on restructuring. To date, we have incurred approximately $60 million of restructuring charges excluding Broadview, compared to our estimate of approximately $150 million for the year. Our original estimate included costs to significantly restructure or shut down certain small operating units. We are now more confident that we will be able to sell certain of these operations which could therefore reduce our restructuring cost by $40 million to $50 million. This would result in full year restructuring charges of approximately $100 million. A majority of these actions we have taken over the last two years are permanent in nature and will not result in increased cost as business conditions continue to improve.  
In addition, we incurred restructuring and acquisition charges of $37 million in the quarter related to the Broadview transaction. We continue to expect these charges will approximate $100 million, of which a large majority will be incurred in the first six months of the acquisition.
Now let me turn the call back over to Ed to wrap up this morning's call.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Overall, I'm quite pleased with our performance so far this year. As I previously mentioned, we have continued to actively manage our portfolio. The Broadview acquisition has increased the recurring revenue portion of our portfolio, and we
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Overall, I'm quite pleased with our performance so far this year. As I previously mentioned, we have continued to actively manage our portfolio. The Broadview acquisition has increased the recurring revenue portion of our portfolio, and we have taken several steps in divesting businesses that do not align with our global strategy. Overall, the actions we have taken this year have further strengthened our core platforms. 
Second, our teams around the world have continued to respond quickly to the continued challenging economic environment. We have managed our cost position well, restructured certain operations and maintained key investments that position our businesses for future growth and continued margin expansion. Lastly, our already-strong balance sheet position has been further strengthened by our refinancing of debt and reduced tax rate.
Now let's turn to our guidance for the fourth quarter. Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect the trends we saw this quarter to continue. We expect fourth quarter revenue of approximately $4.4 billion. The overall operating margin in the fourth quarter should slightly improve from the 10.4% we achieved in the third quarter.
Our debt restructuring should decrease our interest expense by approximately $5 million sequentially, and as Chris explained, our tax rate will approximate 23% in the fourth quarter.  We therefore expect our EPS before special items in the fourth quarter to be in the range of $0.62 to $0.64.
Last quarter, we indicated that we expected EPS to be in the range of $2.50 to $2.58 for the full year, including approximately $0.05 of EPS from our European Waterworks business. As this business is now reported in Discontinued Operations, our full year guidance range would be $2.45 to $2.53 per share. Based on our fourth quarter guidance, we now expect EPS from continuing operations before special items to be in the range of $2.56 to $2.58, which again, excludes the $0.05 of earnings from our Waterworks business. Therefore, our revised guidance of $2.56 to $2.58 is a $0.06 to $0.10 per share increase from our previous guidance.
And with that, operator, let's open up the line for any questions.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: I think we're expecting kind of consistent growth with what we've seen for the past couple of quarters. But the one cautionary piece there, Jeff, is from the time we announced to the time we closed, we did see a decline in the number of sales reps they had as there was a little bit of a challenge replacing sales reps because of the uncertainty. We're now ramping that back up on the ADT side and the Broadview side and look to get that up. But other than that, I don't expect any significant changes to the kind of growth we've been seeing with them.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff, I'll remind you that as we get into the fourth quarter, it's going to be difficult. It's not impossible to break out sort of Broadview revenue versus the normal ADT revenue as we've combined all our marketing programs and the brands. So we'll just be the reporting on ADT revenue. And we'll highlight, obviously, the residential small-business piece of that.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Naren, just more specifically, as you think about these things together in kind of the notion of the best of both, probably in broad terms, the best on the ADT side is subscriber acquisition cost and it's attrition on the Broadview side. And I j
componenttext: And then, Naren, just more specifically, as you think about these things together in kind of the notion of the best of both, probably in broad terms, the best on the ADT side is subscriber acquisition cost and it's attrition on the Broadview side. And I just wonder, what your initial thoughts are now as you've six or eight weeks into this? Where those two can meet? And how you would target those going forward?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Jeff, we are still very early in the integration, so I'm hesitant to draw any conclusions at this time. But based on what we've seen -- and what we expected to see was they're very good from a customer service perspective. We found some inter
componenttext: Well, again, Jeff, we are still very early in the integration, so I'm hesitant to draw any conclusions at this time. But based on what we've seen -- and what we expected to see was they're very good from a customer service perspective. We found some interesting technologies that they used to serve customers better, and actually reduced the cost to serve on the service side, so not just on the attrition side. Clearly, they're very selective upfront on the account acquisition side. We still believe that we will get the subscriber acquisition down closer to where ADT was over time. And then attrition rates, again, for the combined business, we expect to continue to take those down in the same kind of progress we've seen over the past, I'd say, year, excluding the impact of the economy.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, I thought it was nice that we've had a lot of questions around will you have disconnects, because it's now going -- Broadview's going under ADT. You can tell by the disconnect rate -- the ADT disconnect rate improved sequentially, but so did Bro
componenttext: And Jeff, I thought it was nice that we've had a lot of questions around will you have disconnects, because it's now going -- Broadview's going under ADT. You can tell by the disconnect rate -- the ADT disconnect rate improved sequentially, but so did Broadview. And I think that's a real key indicator to kind of an answer to that question, because we've had a fair amount of communication already with the Broadview customer base. So they're well aware of what's taking place and all, and as you know, the attrition rate decline, I thought was a good sign.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Then, Naren, I was wondering if you could also just comment, then again, acknowledging it's probably early, but your initial thoughts on ARPU and what the subscriber acquisition cost looks like for interactive once you kind of include the higher sell, I guess, that would happen at the time of the interactive?

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff, the one caution on this one is we have not really started the advertising campaign to support this. So whatever units we're getting are basically upsells at the kitchen table at this stage. From a pricing perspective, we'd targeted, depending on
componenttext: And Jeff, the one caution on this one is we have not really started the advertising campaign to support this. So whatever units we're getting are basically upsells at the kitchen table at this stage. From a pricing perspective, we'd targeted, depending on which of our three offerings they pursue, anywhere from a $10 to $15 increase in ARPU for those specific products, the kind of the $10 to $12 range, because we expect a mix to be more towards the lower end of the product offering there. Seems to be holding well, but again, we are very early in that rollout right now just in those five test markets. And the subscriber acquisition cost is higher, but that's up being offset by the higher install dollars that we get upfront. So from a net perspective, we're not seeing a significant change there.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some early thoughts on some of the high-level items for 2011? There's a lot of stuff moving around, tax rate, Broadview coming in, Naren gave us [indiscernible] number. We got to think about attempt's been -- just what are your overarching
componenttext: Can you give us some early thoughts on some of the high-level items for 2011? There's a lot of stuff moving around, tax rate, Broadview coming in, Naren gave us [indiscernible] number. We got to think about attempt's been -- just what are your overarching thoughts on how to frame 2011?

componenttextpreview: I'll maybe let Chris jump in maybe on corporate and tax in a moment. And I think Jeff just mentioned a couple of these here. But ADT, because of Broadview coming in, will add $0.10 to earnings next year, so that's a tailwind on an EPS basis. By the way, y
componenttext: I'll maybe let Chris jump in maybe on corporate and tax in a moment. And I think Jeff just mentioned a couple of these here. But ADT, because of Broadview coming in, will add $0.10 to earnings next year, so that's a tailwind on an EPS basis. By the way, you need to take about $0.20 out for Electrical & Metal because we're assuming the spend happens towards the beginning of the year. So that would come out of that number. And I would say, maybe just one other point is, the Flow because we're starting to see the orders improving -- by the way, and they did continue to improve during the month of July. But when you look at the backlog, how it's going in this conversion cycle we're talking about, I think you'll see a nicely stronger second half of next year for Flow, but probably still a little bit muted during the first half of the year until this increased order activity kicks in on a shipment basis. Chris, you might want to add a comment.

headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you look at our corporate expense, for example, I do expect that we'll be able to reduce that again, slightly from where we've been this year. On the tax front, it's still very early to determine what kind of a tax position we'll have. Obv
componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at our corporate expense, for example, I do expect that we'll be able to reduce that again, slightly from where we've been this year. On the tax front, it's still very early to determine what kind of a tax position we'll have. Obviously, we've done a terrific job since the separation in reducing that tax rate, and as we've indicated, Broadview will be a positive. We've got taxing authorities around the world looking at their tax policies right now. So I think between that and obviously, what ends up being our geographic mix of revenues and profits could impact that. But again, we've done a good job in holding that. I don't think anything dramatic there. And then obviously, we'll have the impacts of the share repurchase as we continue to reduce our share count and offset some of that impact of the Broadview acquisition. And then obviously, the refinancing that we have just completed will reduce our interest expense as well.

componenttextpreview: And then what were exactly were purchase accounting charges, not restructuring charges but purchase accounting charges, for Broadview in the quarter? And then I'm just trying to understand, is your guidance, going forward, going to be including Broadview
componenttext: And then what were exactly were purchase accounting charges, not restructuring charges but purchase accounting charges, for Broadview in the quarter? headline: Tyco International Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take that, John. First, in 2010, in the guidance that we have provided, the restructuring and acquisition costs related to the transaction, we have excluded from the guidance. The impact of the purchase accounting, which includes adjustments to the
componenttext: Let me take that, John. First, in 2010, in the guidance that we have provided, the restructuring and acquisition costs related to the transaction, we have excluded from the guidance. The impact of the purchase accounting, which includes adjustments to the deferred revenue base, as well as the subscriber asset base which needs to be amortized, those are operating costs that we have included in our guidance for the year. So there are a lot of adjustments that happened and some pretty complicated purchase accounting adjustments, which generated this $8 million loss for the quarter. Again, that's for a six-week-kind-of-time period. But the normal operating margin that we saw Broadview as a stand alone were essentially the margins that we achieved in the quarter. So no real change there, it's just the noise from the purchase accounting. So I hope that clarifies it.

componenttext: There were $37 million of what I'll call one-time restructuring charges and acquisition costs. That was going from the $0.72 down to the $0.50, but then included in the $0.72 is an $8 million loss from Broadview which is the result of having to write off things like the deferred revenue balance and writing off some of the subscriber base and additional amortization.

componenttextpreview: John, we're still down the road of clearly going towards the spin. We've heard some rumblings out there, that there might be some interest in the business but nothing definitive. My gut is we'll know that answer over the next 60 to 75 days. And if we did
componenttext: John, we're still down the road of clearly going towards the spin. We've heard some rumblings out there, that there might be some interest in the business but nothing definitive. My gut is we'll know that answer over the next 60 to 75 days. And if we did get an offer, clearly, we will assess that and see what the best avenue is for our shareholders. But I'm really -- my thinking at this point, clearly, is we're headed down the spin route.

componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, Nigel, when you look at just our residential business against Broadview business, the gap is not as significant. When you look at our total ARPU, it gets distorted a little bit because of the commercial side of our business. That said, th
componenttext: Just to clarify, Nigel, when you look at just our residential business against Broadview business, the gap is not as significant. When you look at our total ARPU, it gets distorted a little bit because of the commercial side of our business. That said, there is a small gap between the two, and it's really driven more by the content of what they were selling. They had a very simplified package that they were offering. And as we look to add more sensors, more devices there, there's an opportunity to take up that ARPU over time. And again, as we bring the sales force together and standardize the product offering and stuff for that combined sales force, there should be a little bit of a pick up there.

componenttext: But it'll be positive. What happens though, again, I'll try to explain this.
